column2: Top PG programs include: MBA (IMS, PIMR) – Marketing, Finance, HR, IT, MCA (Computer Applications – AICTE Approved), M.Tech (Data Science, Cybersecurity), M.Sc (Biotechnology, Microbiology, Mathematics)

column1: What are the best specializations in MBA in DAVV-affiliated colleges?
column2: The most in-demand MBA specializations are: Finance (Best for Banking & Investment Jobs), Marketing (Best for Digital & Brand Management Jobs), Business Analytics (High demand in Data Science & AI field), HR (Best for Recruitment & HR Consulting Careers)

column1: Which is the best B.Tech specialization in DAVV-affiliated colleges?
column2:
For high-paying jobs, the best B.Tech specializations are: Computer Science & Engineering (CSE) – AI, ML, Web Development
Information Technology (IT) – Software & Cloud Computing, Data Science & Cybersecurity – High growth fields

column1: How to prepare for DAVV CET (Common Entrance Test)?
column2: For BBA/MBA: Focus on Quantitative Aptitude, Logical Reasoning, General Awareness, and English, For MCA: Prepare for Mathematics, Logical Reasoning, and Computer Science basics, For MSc: Study subject-specific topics (Biotech, Mathematics, etc.).

column1: What are the best books for DAVV CET preparation?
column2: Quantitative Aptitude: RS Aggarwal, Arun Sharma, Logical Reasoning: R.S Aggarwal, Arun Sharma, General Awareness: Manorama Yearbook, Lucent’s GK

column1: What is the eligibility for DAVV CET?
column2: UG Courses (BBA, B.Com, BA LLB): Must have 50%+ marks in Class 12, PG Courses (MBA, MCA, M.Sc): Must have 50%+ marks in graduation.

column1: What is the selection process after the DAVV CET?
column2: After clearing the exam, students go through counseling & document verification. Some courses require a personal interview (PI) or group discussion (GD).

column1: s coaching necessary for DAVV CET?
column2: Self-study is enough if students have good reasoning and English skills. However, for MBA/MCA aspirants, coaching for Aptitude & Logical Reasoning may help.

column1: What is the dress code in DAVV-affiliated colleges?
column2: Most colleges allow casual clothing, but some professional courses (MBA, BBA, Law) require formal attire on certain days.

column1: Are there any compulsory attendance rules?
column2: Yes, students must have at least 75% attendance to appear for exams. Low attendance may lead to detention or extra assignments.

column1: What are the common college timings in DAVV-affiliated colleges?
column2: Morning Session: 9 AM – 1 PM, Afternoon Session: 1 PM – 5 PM

column1: Do DAVV-affiliated colleges have student exchange programs?
column2: Some reputed colleges have MoUs with foreign universities, allowing students to study abroad for 1 semester.

column1: What are the career options after completing courses from DAVV-affiliated colleges?
column2: Graduates can explore careers in: Software Development, Data Science, Cybersecurity (for B.Tech, MCA), Banking, Finance, HR, Marketing (for MBA, B.Com), Research, Teaching, Clinical Labs (for M.Sc, B.Sc Biotech).

column1: Which DAVV-affiliated colleges offer B.Tech courses?
column2:
Top colleges offering B.Tech include: IET DAVV (Best for CSE, IT, Mechanical, ECE, Civil)
Acropolis Institute of Technology & Research, IPS Academy Institute of Engineering & Science, Sanghvi Institute of Management & Science

column1: What are the eligibility criteria for B.Tech admission?
column2: Students must have Physics, Chemistry, and Mathematics (PCM) in Class 12 with at least 45% marks. Admission is based on JEE Main scores.

column1: How is B.Tech admission conducted in DAVV-affiliated colleges?
column2: Admission is done through DTE MP Counselling based on JEE Main ranks. Students need to register on MP Online (dte.mponline.gov.in) for choice filling and seat allotment.

column1: What are the most demanded B.Tech specializations?
column2: Computer Science & Engineering (CSE) (Best for Software Development, AI, ML), Information Technology (IT) (Networking, Web Development, Cybersecurity), Data Science & AI (High salary jobs in Analytics, ML, AI), Electronics & Communication Engineering (ECE) (Telecom, Chip Design, IoT), Mechanical & Civil Engineering (Core Industry Jobs).

column1: What are the placement statistics for B.Tech students?
column2:
Top colleges like IET DAVV have 90%+ placement rates. Average package: ₹5-8 LPA 
Highest package: ₹20-25 LPA (Amazon, Microsoft, Google), Companies visiting: TCS, Infosys, Wipro, Cognizant, Deloitte, HCL

column1: What are the internship opportunities for B.Tech students?
column2: Many students get internships in IT companies, government R&D labs, and startups. Some colleges have tie-ups with TCS, Infosys, and DRDO for live projects.

column1: Is hostel available for B.Tech students in DAVV-affiliated colleges?
column2: Yes, government colleges like IET DAVV have hostels, but private colleges provide better hostel facilities with AC, Wi-Fi, and gym access.

column1: Which colleges offer MBA courses under DAVV?
column2: Institute of Management Studies (IMS) DAVV – Best for Finance, Marketing Prestige Institute of Management & Research (PIMR) – Best for HR, Business Analytics Acropolis Faculty of Management & Research IPS Academy School of Management

column1: What is the eligibility for MBA in DAVV-affiliated colleges?
column2: Students must have a bachelor’s degree with at least 50% marks. Admission is based on CMAT scores followed by counseling.

column1: How do I apply for admission?
column2: To apply for admission, visit our college website and complete the online application form with your personal and academic details. After submission, you’ll receive a confirmation email with further instructions, including document submission and fee payment deadlines.

column1: What are the eligibility criteria for undergraduate programs?
column2: Eligibility varies by program, but generally, you need to have completed high school with a minimum GPA of 3.0 and meet specific subject prerequisites. Check the program page on our website for detailed requirements and any additional entrance exam scores needed.

column1: How can students access financial aid?
column2: Students can apply for financial aid by submitting the FAFSA form online and checking our scholarship portal for institutional grants. Our financial aid office is available to guide you through the process and ensure you meet all deadlines.

column1: What is the tuition fee structure?
column2: Tuition fees depend on your program and residency status, for example, in-state students pay around $10,000 per year, while out-of-state students pay $25,000. Detailed breakdowns, including additional fees like housing and books, are available on our finance webpage.

column1: How do I register for classes?
column2: Class registration is done through our student portal after you’ve been admitted and met with an academic advisor. You’ll need your student ID and password, and we recommend registering early to secure your preferred schedule.

column1: Where can students find housing options?
column2: On-campus housing is available through our residence life office, where you can apply for dorms or apartments based on availability. Off-campus options can be explored via our housing board, which lists verified local rentals.

column1: What support services are available for students?
column2: We offer academic advising, tutoring, mental health counseling, and career services to support students throughout their journey. Visit the student services office or website to schedule appointments or access resources tailored to your needs.

column1: How do I get a student ID card?
column2: Once enrolled, visit the campus ID office with a government-issued photo ID to get your student ID card processed. It’s used for library access, dining plans, and event entry, so pick it up early in the semester.

column1: What is the process for dropping a course?
column2: To drop a course, log into the student portal, select the course, and submit a drop request before the deadline, typically the fourth week of the semester. Meet with your advisor first to ensure it won’t affect your graduation plan or financial aid.

column1: How can I contact my professors?
column2: Professors’ contact details, including email and office hours, are listed in the course syllabus and on the faculty directory online. Feel free to reach out for questions or to schedule a meeting—they’re here to help you succeed.

column2: Answer

column1: How can students access financial aid?
column2: Apply through the FAFSA website and check our scholarship portal for additional funding opportunities tailored to your profile. Our financial aid office offers guidance and workshops to help you meet deadlines.

column1: What is the tuition fee structure?
column2: Tuition varies: in-state students pay around $10,000 per year, out-of-state pay $25,000, plus fees for housing and books. A detailed breakdown is available on the finance section of our website.

column1: How do I register for classes?
column2: After advisor approval, log into the student portal with your ID and password to select courses and finalize your schedule. Register early to ensure availability in popular classes.

column1: Where can students find housing options?
column2: Apply for on-campus housing through the residence life office, which offers dorms and apartments based on availability. Off-campus options are listed on our housing board with trusted local rentals.

column1: What support services are available for students?
column2: We offer tutoring, mental health counseling, career advising, and accessibility services to support your success. Check the student services website or visit our office to access these resources.

column1: How do I get a student ID card?
column2: Bring a government-issued photo ID to the campus ID office after enrollment to get your student ID processed. It’s essential for dining, library access, and campus events, so pick it up early.

column1: What is the process for dropping a course?
column2: Log into the student portal, submit a drop request before the fourth week of the semester, and consult your advisor first. This ensures no impact on your academic plan or financial aid status.

column1: How can I contact my professors?
column2: Find their email and office hours in your syllabus or the online faculty directory. They’re approachable and happy to assist with coursework or academic questions.

column1: What are the library hours?
column2: The library operates from 8 AM to 10 PM weekdays and 10 AM to 6 PM weekends, with extended hours during finals week. Check the library website for holiday schedules or unexpected closures.

column1: How do I access my student email?
column2: Use your student ID and the temporary password sent to your personal email to log into your student email account. It’s the primary way we communicate, so monitor it daily.

column1: What happens if I miss a payment deadline?
column2: A $50 late fee applies, and a hold may block your registration or grades until cleared. Contact the bursar’s office ASAP to arrange a payment plan if you’re facing issues.

column1: How do I declare or change my major?
column2: Discuss your plans with your advisor, then submit a major change form via the student portal for processing. It takes about a week, and you’ll be informed of any new requirements.

column1: What health services are available on campus?
column2: Our health center provides free basic care, vaccinations, and counseling with your student ID. Book appointments online, and we offer referrals for emergencies or specialized care.

column1: How do I join a student club?
column2: Explore club options on the student life website, attend an interest meeting, and register with the club leader. It’s a fun way to connect and build skills outside the classroom.

column1: What is the attendance policy?
column2: Each course tracks attendance, more than three unexcused absences may affect your grade per the syllabus. Notify professors ahead of time for excused absences like illness.

column1: How do I apply for a work-study job?
column2: Browse openings on the work-study portal, submit your resume, and interview with the department. Apply early, as positions are competitive and fill quickly.

column1: What are the dining options on campus?
column2: We have dining halls with meal plans and cafes for quick meals, all accessible via your student ID. Let dining services know in advance if you have dietary restrictions.

column1: How do I request a transcript?
column2: Order official transcripts online through the registrar for a fee, or get unofficial ones free via your student account. Processing takes 3-5 days, so plan ahead.

column1: Can I defer my admission?
column2: Yes, submit a deferral request to admissions before the semester starts, explaining your reason. Approval grants a one-year delay, but you’ll need to reapply if longer.

column1: What’s the transfer credit policy?
column2: Submit transcripts to the registrar for evaluation, credits from accredited schools typically transfer if they match our curriculum. You’ll get a report within two weeks detailing accepted credits.

column1: How do I appeal a grade?
column2: Discuss with your professor first, then file an appeal with the academic affairs office within 30 days if unresolved. Include evidence like assignments to support your case.

column1: What’s the policy on incompletes?
column2: Request an incomplete from your professor before finals if extenuating circumstances apply, like illness. You’ll have one semester to finish the work, or it turns to an F.

column1: Can I get a tuition refund?
column2: Refunds are possible if you withdraw before the add/drop deadline, typically week two, after that, it’s prorated. Check the bursar’s refund schedule for exact percentages.

column1: How do I appeal a financial aid decision?
column2: Submit an appeal letter to the financial aid office with documentation, like medical bills or income changes. They’ll review it within two weeks and adjust if eligible.

column1: How do I reserve a study room?
column2: Book study rooms online through the library website using your student ID, they’re free but time-limited. Reserve early during finals when demand spikes.

column1: What’s the guest policy in dorms?
column2: Guests must sign in at the dorm desk with ID and leave by midnight unless pre-approved for overnight. Residents are responsible for their guests’ behavior.

column1: How do I reset my portal password?
column2: Use the ‘forgot password’ link on the portal login page and follow the prompts to reset via your student email. IT support can assist if you hit technical issues.

column1: What software is free for students?
column2: Microsoft Office, Adobe Acrobat Reader, and some discipline-specific tools are free with your student login. Check the IT website for a full list and download instructions.

column1: How do I get an internship?
column2: Visit the career center for listings, polish your resume with their help, and apply directly to employers. They also host fairs to connect you with opportunities.

column1: When do I apply for graduation?
column2: Apply via the registrar’s portal one semester before your expected graduation date, usually by mid-term. Late applications may delay your diploma, so don’t miss it.

column1: What’s the emergency protocol?
column2: In emergencies, call campus security at the posted number or use blue light phones, they’ll coordinate with local services. Check the safety website for drills and updates.

column1: How do I report a safety concern?
column2: Submit concerns via the online safety form or call the security office directly, available 24/7. We investigate all reports and follow up promptly.

column1: What’s the lost and found process?
column2: Check the campus lost and found at the student union, items are held for 30 days before donation. Report lost items online to help us match them.

column1: How do I update my contact info?
column2: Log into the student portal, update your address or phone under ‘personal info,’ and save changes. It’s critical for emergency notifications and billing.

column1: Can I take courses at another college?
column2: Yes, get pre-approval from your advisor and the registrar to ensure credits transfer back here. Submit transcripts afterward to update your record.

column1: What’s the policy on academic probation?
column2: If your GPA drops below 2.0, you’re on probation and must meet with an advisor to create a recovery plan. Failure to improve may lead to suspension.

column1: How do I access online course materials?
column2: Log into the learning management system with your student ID, materials are posted by professors. Contact IT if you can’t access your courses.

column1: What’s the parking policy?
column2: Purchase a parking permit online and display it on your vehicle, spaces are first-come, first-served. Violations like parking without a permit result in fines.

column1: How do I get involved in research?
column2: Ask professors in your department about openings or check the research office for funded projects. Undergrads often start as assistants and can earn credit.

column1: What’s the process for withdrawing?
column2: Meet with your advisor, then submit a withdrawal form to the registrar before semester’s end. Refunds and transcripts depend on timing, so check policies.

column1: Can I audit a course?
column2: Yes, with instructor permission, register to audit via the portal, it’s free but won’t earn credits. It’s a great way to explore without grade pressure.

column1: How do I file a complaint?
column2: Submit complaints via the student affairs online form or in person, include details for faster resolution. We aim to respond within a week.

column1: What’s the gym schedule?
column2: The gym is open 6 AM to 11 PM daily, with adjusted hours on holidays posted online. Bring your student ID for free access to equipment and classes.

column1: How do I get a locker?
column2: Request a locker at the gym or student union desk, they’re free but limited, so sign up early. Bring your own lock and clear it out by semester’s end.

column1: What’s the policy on pets in dorms?
column2: Only service animals are allowed in dorms, emotional support animals need prior approval from disability services. Violations can lead to fines or removal.

column1: How do I access career counseling?
column2: Schedule an appointment with the career center online or drop in during walk-in hours. They’ll help with resumes, interviews, and job search strategies.

column1: What’s the process for late registration?
column2: After the regular period, petition the registrar with a valid reason, like a medical delay, and pay a late fee. Approval isn’t guaranteed, so act fast.

column1: How do I check my grades?
column2: Log into the student portal after finals, grades post within a week of semester end. Contact your professor if you spot an error.

column1: What is the minimum CGPA required for college admission?
column2: Most colleges require a minimum CGPA of 2.5 to 3.0, but it varies by institution and program.
column3: Check the specific college’s website for exact requirements.

column1: How do I apply for financial aid?
column2: Complete the FAFSA form online at fafsa.gov to apply for federal aid.
column3: Contact your college’s financial aid office for additional scholarships or grants.

column1: What standardized tests are required for admission?
column2: Many colleges require SAT or ACT scores, though some are test-optional.
column3: Verify the policy of each school you’re applying to.

column1: When is the application deadline for most colleges?
column2: Regular decision deadlines are typically January 1st, but early decision is often November.
column3: Always confirm exact dates on the college’s admissions page.

column1: Can I apply to multiple colleges at once?
column2: Yes, you can apply to as many colleges as you’d like using platforms like the Common App.
column3: Keep track of deadlines and requirements for each school.

column1: What is the Common App?
column2: The Common App is an online platform to apply to over 900 colleges with one application.
column3: It simplifies the process but may require supplemental essays for some schools.

column1: How important are extracurricular activities for admission?
column2: They show leadership and passion, boosting your application beyond grades.
column3: Focus on quality over quantity in your involvement.

column1: What should I write in my college essay?
column2: Write a personal, authentic story that highlights your character and goals.
column3: Avoid generic topics and proofread carefully.

column1: Do I need recommendation letters for college?
column2: Most colleges require 1-3 letters from teachers or counselors.
column3: Choose recommenders who know you well and can speak to your strengths.

column1: How do I know if a college is a good fit for me?
column2: Consider size, location, majors, campus culture, and cost.
column3: Visit campuses or attend virtual tours to decide.

column1: What is Early Decision, and should I apply for it?
column2: Early Decision is a binding application submitted by November, with decisions by December.
column3: It’s best if you’re certain of your top-choice school.

column1: Can international students apply to U.S. colleges?
column2: Yes, international students can apply but may need TOEFL/IELTS scores.
column3: Check for visa requirements and financial aid options.

column1: What’s the difference between a college and a university?
column2: Colleges are smaller and focus on undergraduate degrees, universities offer graduate programs too.
column3: Choose based on your academic and career goals.

column1: How do I submit my high school transcript?
column2: Request your school counselor to send it electronically or by mail to the college.
column3: Ensure it’s official and sealed for acceptance.

column1: What happens if I miss an application deadline?
column2: You may need to wait for the next admission cycle or apply as a late applicant.
column3: Contact the admissions office to explore options.

column1: How much does it cost to apply to college?
column2: Application fees range from $25 to $90 per school, though some offer waivers.
column3: Check for fee waiver eligibility if cost is a concern.

column1: What is a waitlist, and how does it work?
column2: A waitlist means you’re qualified but not yet accepted due to limited spots.
column3: You may be admitted later if space opens up.

column1: Can I change my major after I enroll?
column2: Yes, most colleges allow major changes, often within the first two years.
column3: Check with academic advisors for specific policies.

column1: What is rolling admission?
column2: Rolling admission reviews applications as they arrive, offering decisions quickly.
column3: Apply early for the best chance at acceptance and aid.

column1: How do I prepare for a college interview?
column2: Research the school, practice common questions, and be yourself.
column3: Dress professionally and arrive with thoughtful questions.

column1: Question
column2: Answer

column1: What are the hostel facilities like?
column2: Hostels offer Wi-Fi, laundry, and 24/7 security services. Students can opt for single or shared rooms.

column1: Are there medical facilities on campus?
column2: A health center with doctors is available on-site. Emergency care is accessible around the clock.

column1: What clubs can students join?
column2: Over 30 clubs like debate and music are offered. Students can also propose new clubs.

column1: How are extracurricular events organized?
column2: Staff and students plan fests and workshops together. Participation is open to everyone.

column1: How many books are in the college library?
column2: The library has over 50,000 books and e-journals. It’s open daily for 12 hours.

column1: Can staff borrow books for research?
column2: Staff enjoy unlimited borrowing privileges. Digital resources support research needs.

column1: What is the placement rate for graduates?
column2: Over 85% of graduates find jobs quickly. Top firms recruit on campus yearly.

column1: How does the placement cell support students?
column2: The cell offers resume help and mock interviews. It links students to recruiters.

column1: What sports facilities are available?
column2: Fields for soccer and cricket are provided. A modern gym is open to all.

column1: Are there inter-college sports competitions?
column2: We host and join regional sports tournaments. Tryouts select the teams.

column1: What is the application deadline?
column2: Applications are due by May 31st for fall. Late entries may be waitlisted.

column1: How do we process international applications?
column2: We review academics and visa requirements. Processing takes 4 to 6 weeks.

column1: Are scholarships available for new students?
column2: Merit and need-based scholarships are offered. Apply with grades and financial docs.

column1: How is financial aid disbursed?
column2: Aid is credited to accounts each semester. Eligibility is checked yearly.

column1: What majors are offered?
column2: Over 20 majors like engineering are available. The full list is online.

column1: How are course schedules planned?
column2: Faculty set schedules based on demand. Updates occur each semester.

column1: Is there campus Wi-Fi?
column2: Wi-Fi covers all areas and is free. Students log in with their ID.

column1: How do we maintain campus cleanliness?
column2: A team cleans facilities daily for hygiene. Issues can be reported anytime.

column1: Are there music programs?
column2: Bands and choirs are open to all levels. Auditions happen each term.

column1: Who oversees club budgets?
column2: Staff advisors manage funds with students. Budgets are set yearly.

column1: Are e-books available?
column2: Thousands of e-books are online for use. Access them with your student ID.

column1: How do we update library resources?
column2: We review data and requests annually. New items are added as needed.

column1: Which companies recruit here?
column2: Firms like Google and TCS visit campus. Diverse opportunities are ensured.

column1: How do we track placement success?
column2: Surveys of graduates and employers are done. Data improves our programs.

column1: Can beginners join sports teams?
column2: Beginners are welcome with training offered. Tryouts are open to all.

column1: How are sports facilities funded?
column2: Funds come from tuition and donations. Upgrades follow student feedback.

column1: What are the SAT score requirements?
column2: A 1200 score is recommended, not required. We review applications holistically.

column1: How do we evaluate applications?
column2: Grades, scores, and essays are assessed. Each applicant gets fair consideration.

column1: Can I work on campus for aid?
column2: Part-time jobs like library assistant are open. Earnings help with tuition.

column1: How do we verify aid eligibility?
column2: Income and academic records are checked. A 3.0 GPA is needed for renewal.

column1: Are there online courses?
column2: Select courses are offered online each term. Check the portal for details.

column1: How do we ensure teaching quality?
column2: Faculty are reviewed by students and peers. Training keeps them updated.

column1: Is there a cafeteria on campus?
column2: The cafeteria serves affordable diverse meals. It’s open daily for students.

column1: How do we handle facility repairs?
column2: Repairs are logged online and fixed fast. Urgent issues get priority.

column1: Are there theater groups?
column2: A drama club performs two plays yearly. Auditions welcome everyone.

column1: How do we promote student events?
column2: Events are shared via email and posters. Staff and students work together.

column1: Can I request specific books?
column2: Requests can be made online or in-person. We’ll source books if possible.

column1: How do we manage overdue books?
column2: Fines apply after a grace period ends. Reminders are sent to borrowers.

column1: Are internships offered?
column2: Paid internships are available via partners. Apply through the placement cell.

column1: How do we prepare students for interviews?
column2: Workshops and coaching sessions are held. Mock interviews build skills.

column1: Is there a swimming pool?
column2: An Olympic-size pool is open year-round. Free lessons are provided.

column1: How do we select team captains?
column2: Captains are picked for skill and leadership. Coaches and peers decide.

column1: Can I defer my admission?
column2: Deferrals are allowed for one year. Submit a written request to proceed.

column1: How do we handle waitlisted students?
column2: Waitlisted students are contacted if spots open. Decisions are made by July.

column1: Are there loans available?
column2: Low-interest loans are offered via partners. Terms depend on the lender.

column1: How do we process aid appeals?
column2: Appeals are reviewed monthly by committee. Submit docs for consideration.

column1: Can I change my major?
column2: Major changes are allowed in year one. Discuss with an advisor first.

column1: How do we support struggling students?
column2: Free tutoring and counseling are provided. Faculty track student progress.

column1: Are there study lounges?
column2: Quiet lounges with Wi-Fi are open 24/7. They’re equipped for studying.

column1: How do we ensure campus safety?
column2: Security patrols and cameras run 24/7. Emergency lines are always open.

column1: Are there part-time job fairs?

column1: What sports leagues do we join?

column1: How do we assign roommates?

column1: Is there a student government?

column1: Are there vegan meal options?

column1: Can I appeal my financial aid?
column2: Appeals are reviewed with new documentation. Submit by the semester deadline.

column1: What’s the campus parking policy?
column2: Parking is free for registered student vehicles. Spots are limited, so apply early.

column1: Are there mental health services?
column2: Counselors offer free sessions for students. Appointments are confidential.

column1: How do we train sports coaches?
column2: Coaches attend annual workshops for skills. They’re certified professionals.

column1: Is there a lost and found?
column2: Lost items are kept at the admin office. Check within 30 days to claim.

column1: What are the lab facilities like?
column2: Labs have modern equipment for all majors. They’re open during class hours.

column1: How do we handle power outages?
column2: Backup generators keep campus running. Outages are rare and fixed fast.

column1: Are there photography clubs?
column2: A photography club meets weekly for shoots. Equipment is provided free.

column1: What’s the average class size?
column2: Classes average 25 students for interaction. Labs may be smaller.

column1: Can I access the gym off-season?
column2: The gym stays open year-round for all. Hours adjust during breaks.

column1: How do we fund student projects?
column2: Grants and college funds support projects. Apply through the dean’s office.

column1: Are there language courses?
column2: Courses in Spanish, French, and more are offered. They’re open to beginners.

column1: What’s the hostel curfew?
